episode.title: Janus Capital Group v. First Derivative Traders

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We will hear argument first this morning in Case 09-525, Janus Capital Group v. First Derivative Traders.
Mr. Perry.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Affirming the judgment below would authorize private securities fraud class actions against every service provider that participates in the drafting of a public company's prospectus.
It is therefore nothing less than a frontal assault on this Court's decisions in Central Bank and Stoneridge.
In those cases, Your Honors, this Court held that service providers may not be sued primarily in private class actions and left that matter for Congress to resolve.
And Congress did respond, not once, not twice, but three times, to those decisions.
First, in the PSLRA, the Congress authorized a Federal action, a government action, only against aiders and abettors, leaving the question of private class actions for this Court's resolution.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Counsel, is -- who is the violator alleged here?
Not in the complaint, but in the briefs?

As I read the briefs, they claim that Janus itself did not make the false statement, that the two appellants did, that they are the actual speakers because they were talking about their activities, and they used Janus as a conduit to deceive the market.
That's, I think, what they're alleging.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Justice Sotomayor, the challenge statements appear in the prospectuses for the Janus Funds, separate legal entities not parties to this lawsuit.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So how do we sustain the intermediary cases when the company, through market analysts, divulges misleading statements?
We don't talk about the market analysts' falsity; we talk about the company's falsity, because the market analysts didn't have scienter.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Your Honor, the company -- excuse me -- the conduit or analyst cases fall under two categories, neither of which is met here.
First, they are a scheme between the company -- orchestrated by the company to distribute its information through the analysts to the market, and they are brought under 10b-5(a) as scheme cases.
That is most of the analyst cases.
There is no 10b-5(a) claim in this case.
This is only a 10b-5(b)-making claim.
Second, those few cases, the analyst cases that are brought under (b), involve an admission; that is, the company has failed to correct a statement made by an analyst where there is a duty to do so.
There is no omission claim in this case because there is no duty--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Well, what's the difference between an omission or a commission if a company purposely divulges a falsehood to an analyst, knowing it's going to be distributed and told?
So who is making the false statement, the analyst or the company?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor, the company makes the statement to the market.
Under basic, the analyst is the market.
It is the ears of the market that takes the information.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So why isn't -- why aren't the two appellants, on their theory, on -- we can talk about whether the complaint does or does not adequately allege their theory.
That's a different issue.
I accept that.
But under their theory, why isn't the appellants the primary violator, not even a secondary?

Because they -- they claim, I think -- and I'm going to find out from them -- that Janus had no scienter, that it didn't make the false statements, that all of this was done in secret by the appellants, so they were the only violator.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Your Honor, the analyst cases, the issuer speaks to the market directly.
Here, there is an intervening legal entity, the Janus Funds.
Scienter or no scienter, that is a separate corporation--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Do you mean to say to me that puppets become a legal defense for someone who intentionally manipulates the market information?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Justice Sotomayor, the Congress has drafted two statutes that deal with puppets.
Section 20(b), which these plaintiffs have not invoked, makes it unlawful for one party to do indirectly what it would not be permitted to do directly.
That's the puppet statute, the ventriloquist dummy statute.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: That's the control person statute?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: No.
There is also 20(a), which is the control person statute, also not invoked by these plaintiffs.
Those are forms of secondary liability, Your Honor.
In fact, the Court's questions go to the distinction between primary and secondary liability.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But I -- but if Janus had no scienter, if its board of directors did not know that the statements were false, they had no way of knowing, because as I understand the complaint, and this is alleged, the deal was secret.
So Janus itself could not be a primary violator.
Who is?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Justice Sotomayor, our position is nobody had scienter, and every adjudicator to look at these facts -- Judge Mott in the district court, the ALJ of the SEC, has found that there was no scienter anywhere up and down the line.
So the fact that somebody didn't have scienter doesn't answer the problem here.
The question--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, somebody deviated from what was the announced policy -- that there was to be no market timers investing in this -- in these Janus Funds.
Somebody made the decision that certain hedge funds would be allowed to engage in that activity.
Who was that somebody?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --The advisor personnel made the determination, Justice Ginsburg, that the policy was discretionary, that when it said we may refuse trades, the Funds may refuse trades, that there are discretion--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, the statement that's alleged to have been -- the conduct that is alleged to have been in opposition to the announced policy, that is attributable squarely to -- this is the entity called JCM?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So it made the decision that violated the policy?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
And the SEC--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Nonetheless, it's not a primary actor?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Not as to these plaintiffs, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But can -- can -- can we discuss the case, and -- and -- and perhaps you don't think so.
Can't we discuss this case, must we not discuss this case, on the theory that JCM's scienter, JCM's knowledge of a false statement, is a given in the case?
Now, maybe you'll be able to prove otherwise.
You say that they're not liable anyway.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, you're exactly right.
That is the theory pleaded in the complaint.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And it seems to me that's what the argument here is mostly about.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: And the question that is before this Court, we would submit, is whether, scienter or no scienter, JCM can be held liable for the statements in another company's prospectus.
This Court has never held--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Even though there was no scheme with another actor?
Even though it was the only violator, which is a fair reading of the complaint?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --They chose not to bring a scheme case.
And remember, there is a second set of investors here: The fund investors.
The SEC brought an action, secured $100 million on behalf of them.
There was a series of private litigation that has been resolved, brought by those investors.
These investors did not purchase the securities offered by the -- the prospectus they challenge.
And again, there's a fundamental disconnect between the defendant in the case and the challenge--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But once again -- once again, if the complainants in the case, the plaintiffs in the case -- hypothetical case, not this case, hypothetical case -- were injured shareholders the Fund, I take it you say still they could not sue JCM?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor, for different reasons.
They can sue JCM for -- for an omission, because there's a duty that runs from JCM the Fund.
That was the theory advanced in that separate lawsuit accepted by the district court, which has since been resolved.
They can't -- these plaintiffs can't bring an omission case, because there is no duty that runs from JCM out to the JCG shareholders.
The district court held that.
They didn't appeal that to the Fourth Circuit.
They didn't present that in their cert petition.
So they can't bring that omissions case.
Any wrongdoing in this case -- Justice Ginsburg, to finish my answer to your question, the policy says funds are not intended for market timing.
The advisor allowed 12 traders to trade frequently.
The only wrongdoing, if there is any wrongdoing, was the failure of the advisor to disclose to the trustees the deviation from the policy.
That is a State law breach of contract.
It may be a breach of fiduciary duty.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, Mr. Perry, who wrote the relevant statements?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Your Honor, the Fund made the statements to the public.
They were drafted--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: I understand that they were in the Fund's prospectus, but who wrote them?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --They were drafted by lawyers for the Fund, lawyers representing the Fund.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Who paid those lawyers?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: The advisor paid the lawyers' salaries.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: So JCM paid the lawyers?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: And so it was JCM's lawyers who wrote the prospectus, including the relevant statements here, the asserted misrepresentations?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: I -- I disagree with that, Justice Kagan.
They don't allege that in the complaint, and the facts show that the lawyers--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, suppose the complaint had alleged that.
Suppose the complaint had simply said: JCM's lawyers authored the relevant statements in the prospectus.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --One would have to--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Would that be enough to survive a motion to dismiss?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
One would have to further look at who those lawyers were representing.
The truth in the real world is--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: They're paid by JCM.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Every prospectus is written by lawyers, Justice Kagan.
Lawyers write prospectuses.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: These are in-house counsel for the investment advisor.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: In-house counsel, outside counsel, once they draft materials and present them to their client, it becomes the client's statement when adopted by the client.
The board of trustees the Funds has to review every policy, is responsible for every policy drafted, by inside counsel, outside counsel, consultants.
It's not unusual for companies to retain outside service providers to provide any number of policies: Employment policies, investment policies, anything else.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Perry, you -- you said that it was the Fund's lawyers who drafted the prospectus, but in fact, it was JCM's lawyers, the lawyers -- they were in-house lawyers for JCM.
And they served -- served the Fund in doing this prospectus, but they were on the payroll of JCM, and they were JCM's legal department.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Your Honor, like all lawyers, they wear multiple hats.
I represent multiple clients.
These lawyers represent multiple clients.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought they were in-house lawyers?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: They are in-house lawyers at JCM, but they also represent the Funds, and the SEC has specifically recognized in the context of investment companies that where an advisor counsel is representing the Funds, his client or her client, for those purposes, is the Funds.
And here, these lawyers are very careful to separate who their -- their clients are for various purposes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, let's say that JCM's principal officers and managers wrote the statement.
You still say there's nobody?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Absolutely, Justice Kennedy, because when the statement is adopted by the issuer, it becomes the issuer's statement.
Only an issuer can make the statement.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.
It's not attributable, at least publicly, to JCM.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: That's--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is there an alternate theory that JCM is really the day-to-day managers in day-to-day active control of the Fund, and therefore, it should be chargeable as if it and the Fund are the same for purposes of making the statement?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And we would say that that's different from, say, an outside law firm or an auditor?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor, the word "control" appears more than a hundred times in the briefs on the plaintiff's side of this case in this Court, and the Congress has dealt with control.
Section 20(a) provides a separate cause of action against those who control another entity.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Except that I, as I read your brief, and you can correct me if I'm wrong, you were arguing that since there was an independent board of directors, presumably because there are two corporate -- different corporate funds -- two different corporate forms, that there couldn't be control person liability under 20(a).
You seem that -- I thought, reading your brief, that's what you were alleging.
So you can't have your cake and eat it, too.
Either the independence of the board makes no difference or it does, so which is your position?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Our position, Your Honor, is that the Congress has dealt with the situation where you have two separate companies and to make a claim against the second company, you have to prove control.
Whether or not they could in this case, none of us knows, because they never brought that claim.
They represented to the district court--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Under what theory would you defend an allegation that the investment manager who had control over the everyday affairs of the company, drafted or helped draft the prospectus, hired the lawyers who helped draft it, wouldn't be a control person?
How would you defend that?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor, the investment company, the mutual funds, are separately owned, separately governed.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Exactly.
So you -- you're -- if they can't be control persons because they're separate companies, then how do they escape being primary violators?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, then -- then we're just saying that the investment advisor is a service provider like every other service provider.
They are like the--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But it's not in this case, because the allegation is that it -- not the company, that it chose to deceive the market.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Your Honor, with respect, the allegation is that the advisor wrote a certain policy, but the very document cited for that in the complaint says that the trustees are responsible for the policies of the funds.
The trustees, when they adopt them, it becomes the corporate policies of them.
I mean, on the plaintiff's--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Perry, does the Fund have employees?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
The Fund has--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Who are the Fund's employees?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Are the officers of the Fund, the chief executive officer, the chief financial officer--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Are all of the employees also employees of JCM?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Not the president, Your Honor, but the others are joint -- serve in joint capacities.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: And could you just run through a little bit how one of these prospectuses gets -- gets issues eventually?
The JCM lawyers start the process by drafting, and then what happens?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: The lawyers representing the trusts, both in-house and external, draft the underlying document--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, here, I believe there was a statement in your interrogatories that it's JCM's lawyers, in-house lawyers, who drafted the relevant statement.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --The particular prospectus, answered in that prospectus.
That's exactly right.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: And then what happens?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: They are presented to the board of trustees, which holds a meeting.
The board of trustees is -- the Funds are represented by outside counsel and the independent trustees are represented by outside counsel.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Was there any change to these statements made by the board of trustees?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: These particular statements?

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
There were changes to the market timing policy throughout the class period.
In fact, earlier in the class period there was a disclosure that market timing might be permitted pursuant to a -- a written contract.
That was revised later.
The trustees asked multiple questions.
They were back and forth with their lawyers.
Outside counsel was always involved, and there were other consultants involved periodically as well.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Does the outside counsel you're talking about represent the Fund only?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: There is two separate sets of outside counsel.
One law firm represents only the Fund.
It does not represent the advisor; only represents the Funds, Your Honor.
There's a second law firm in this case that represents the independent trustees.
Six of the seven trustees determined that to secure their independence, because the chairman of the board at that time was an interested person under the statute, they have a separate law firm.
There are two law firms that have nothing to do with the advisors.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But the law firm that -- the lawyers who drafted the prospectus were in-house counsel for JCM on JCM's payroll?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: They were paid by JCM, and at the time they drafted, they were representing the Funds, again, as allowed by the SEC, as disclosed in the documents--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But they weren't the independent outside lawyers who were representing the board or the Fund; they were the in-house counsel?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Those outside counsel reviewed every policy.
In fact, if you look at the--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I guess my question was simply: The drafters of the prospectus were the in-house counsel for JCM?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --The -- the paragraph being challenged in this case, that's correct, Your Honor.
The interrogatory response doesn't speak more broadly than that, but I agree with that.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I suppose if the lawyers for the trust did an inadequate job of reviewing the JCM drafts, they would be subject to a malpractice action by the trust?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Correct, Your Honor.
And then the trust, of course, has contractual and other rights against the advisor that it has enforced, you know, in this very case.
The trustees made a claim against the advisor for all of this underlying conduct.
Except--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What happens if the president of the oil company, knowing that the statement is false, says: We have discovered 42 trillion barrels of oil in Yucatan.
He writes it on a piece of paper; he gives it to the board of trustees; they think it's true and they issue it.
Joe Smith buys stock and later loses money.
Can Joe Smith sue the president of Yucatan, of the oil company, for having made an untrue statement of material fact?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --If he's an authorized agent of the same company that issued the statement?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What he is -- he didn't issue it.
What he did was he gave it to the board of trustees, who issued it.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: If the board of trustees of his company, so that the statement--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: He's the president of the company.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --And the distinction here, Justice Breyer, is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no.
I'm asking what happens.
Is there recovery?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --If he is an authorized agent, he may be sued as--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: He is running the business, the daily affairs, of the company.
Of course the president of a company is an authorized agent of the company, and so, yes.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --He may be subject to liability, then.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, if he is subject to liability, why isn't your firm, your client, subject to liability, who, after all, run every affair of the Fund?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Your Honor, they run the management of the Fund.
The investment of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, that's what a president does.
The president of a company manages the company.
And if the president is liable, why isn't the group of people who do everything for the company -- why aren't they liable?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Because the corporate form has meaning in the Federal law and in State law, and where--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, you have to explain it to me more.
I'm not being difficult.
I understand this less well than you think I do, and I want to know.
That's an obvious, naive question, and I would like an answer that anyone could understand.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --The answer is, Your Honor: These funds are managed -- governed, excuse me, is a better word -- by the trustees.
That is disclosed in these documents.
In fact, the documents say -- it's at page 258A of the Joint Appendix -- the trustees are responsible for all the policies.
They have outsourced, if you will, certain functions, operational functions: Which stock to buy, which stock to sell, which transfer agent to hire.
Those are functions that could be kept in house, but could be--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I get it.
In other words, you're saying on the papers here, it's -- it's the trustees that manage everything.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --That govern everything.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: That govern everything, and these are like helpers?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Well, they're -- they're--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They do a lot as helpers.

Now, let me suggest to you, if that's one possible distinction, what about this distinction: That the managers of a Fund, even though they are outsourced people brought in, are liable as principals, not aiders or abettors, if -- following criminal law here, if -- they are principals if they get the false statement to the public through a conduit, the conduit being an entity or person that is unaware of the falsity of the statement?
That's LaFave on criminal law.
What is -- what about that?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Three answers.
First, as dealt with in section 20(b), which is the ventriloquist dummy statute that these plaintiffs didn't invoke.
Second, the Congress looked at this very question in 1938 and 1939, when there were proposals to merge the management, the advisor function, with the funds, to make them one unitary entity.
In the Investment Company Act of 1940 and the Investment Advisors Act of 1940 the Congress elected not do that.
As this Court has recognized, it chose not to require compulsorily internalization of the management function.
It allowed this separate entity.
And therefore, when you have separate companies, under State law -- again, my client is a Delaware limited liability corporation.
The Funds are Massachusetts business trusts.
They have nothing in common.
There's no joint ownership, no joint governance--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Could you--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: You're -- you're not suggesting, are you, that they did this for purposes of protecting your client from lawsuit?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Absolutely not.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: When it -- no, they did it for a business reason, that having separate entities was economically more useful for the market, correct?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: And every fund, or virtually every fund in -- in the United States, is set up this way.
And again--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So -- but that doesn't answer Justice Breyer's question, now.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --My third--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Assuming that they didn't do it for that reason, what does it mean?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --My third answer is that extensive regulatory involvement in the two acts enacted in 1940 specifically to regulate this industry, that Congress never made the decision to hold the advisor liable for the Fund's conduct.
In fact, no statute says that, and the SEC has never taken that position.
There is no case cited in any of the briefs -- they have 234 pages, 138 cases.
Not one holds an investment advisor liable for statements of the fund's prospectuses.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Just -- just to clarify Justice Breyer's hypothetical.

In your -- in the hypothetical you gave where the president gives an innocent board of directors false information and the prospectus goes out, is the company liable because their agent -- is the company liable under 10b-5?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: The company may be sued under 10b-5.
It has got to meet all the elements.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: But yes, it is an authorized agent making a statement on behalf of the company.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So what you're saying is that the -- the agency relation that the president of the company holds is different that than the agency relation that JCM holds?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: Absolutely right, Your Honor, and that's a distinction--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why is that?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --It's grounded in State law, and it differs between one company and two companies.
Where Congress has looked at issuers, for example--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, but is JCM an agent?
Are you acknowledging that they're an agent of -- of the Fund?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --You know, for certain purposes, Justice Scalia, they are an agent.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What -- what purposes are that?
For purposes of -- at issue here?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: No, Your Honor, for -- not for drafting a prospectus.
For carrying out the investment function.
They are laid out in the contract--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay--

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --It's attached as an appendix to our brief, which sets forth the things that JCM is an agent for investment operations, not an agent specifically for registering the Fund's securities for sales, complying with the Federal securities laws, preparing and issuing the prospectus.
All those things, by contrast--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: So even though they did those things, they acted in excess of their authority?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --They did not do those things, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But that's the allegation.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: No, it's not the allegation.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, suppose it were proved that they did do those things.
Suppose it were proven that they did 100 percent of prospectus work.
The only thing that the Fund did was to mail it.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: I don't know how to respond to that, Justice Kennedy, since it's so far beyond what they could possibly prove here.
What happened here--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, this case -- this case went off on -- in the district court, it was -- was it 12b-6?

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Okay.
And all that the Fourth Circuit said is, it goes beyond; it has to go further.
And the -- the impression that I got from the Fourth Circuit's opinion is -- and it could be reduced to a very simple statement.
They say: JCM was in the driver's seat.
It was running the show.
And if that can be proved, they thought that they would have a good case under--

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: And, Your Honor, no court, no case from this Court or any court of appeals has ever held that the driver's seat exception, the central bank, exists.
And that is an expansion.
The second issue in the case, of course, which is attribution: Even if there is making by JCM, none of these statements were attributed to JCM.
The prospectus is very clear that at issue--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --But that was -- I mean, before you started out with statements that sounded like the sky is falling because lawyers would no longer be safe, banks would no longer be safe -- but the Fourth Circuit was -- was a much narrower view.
Its view was, this -- JCM was the manager.
It was controlling everything.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Justice Ginsburg, the Fourth Circuit's view was the manager helps the Fund.
That -- nobody even defends the Fourth Circuit's ruling.
The government now comes in with a theory that they admit, on page 22 of the government's brief, does apply to every lawyer, every accountant, every--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --I thought that the question on which we granted cert was very clear: whether the Fourth Circuit erred in concluding that a service provider can be held primarily liable in the private securities fraud action for, quote, "helping", close quote, or, quote, "participating in", close quote, another company's misstatements.
Now, is -- is that an accurate description of the Court's holding?
It was not objected to by the Respondent here.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --Absolutely, Justice Scalia.
And that question can only be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And that's what I thought we granted.
We weren't talking about control here.
That -- that was not the issue, I thought.

turn.speaker: mark_a_perry
turn.label: Mr. Mark A. Perry
turn.text: --We agree with the Court.
The question presented can only be answered one way: The court of appeals erred.
If I may reserve my remaining time.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Thank you, Counsel.
Mr. Frederick.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Frederick, is that an accurate description of -- of the question before us?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: I don't think it is, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why didn't you object to it in -- in your -- in your opposition?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: We did object, in the sense that we described the complaint's allegations as JCM writing and preparing and being responsible for the prospectus.
And the question of--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't -- but we -- we don't reevaluate facts.
We -- we review the holding of a lower court.
Now, was this an accurate description of the holding of the Fourth Circuit?
And if it wasn't, why didn't you say that in your brief in opposition?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --We did say it in our brief in opposition, Justice Scalia, and the Solicitor General, when you called for the views of the Solicitor General, also said in the invitation brief that this case was not an appropriate vehicle for deciding just simply JCM was responsible for the prospectuses in all their various aspects: In writing, preparing, et cetera.
And so we--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: How can -- I'm sorry.
Please--

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --So we would submit that for the reasons we stated in our opposition and we stated in our red brief, as the case comes to this Court on reviewing a motion to dismiss of a complaint's well-pleaded allegations -- and I can go through the complaint's allegations if you like that explain how JCM wrote and prepared the prospectus and the policies for the Fund and then implemented them falsely -- we would submit this case is not about service providers, but it is about Janus Capital Management being the primary violator.
They were the ones who had the motive to lie, they had the incentive to lie, and they did lie.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Did they make the statements?
Isn't that the statutory text that we're dealing with?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Yes, they did.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They did make the statements?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Yes, they composed and created--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It didn't go out under their name.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --It did, in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If someone writes a speech for me, one can say he drafted the speech, but I make the speech.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, we address the definition of SEC's interpretation, which is entitled to deference, as to being to create or to compose or to accept as one's own.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's not what -- it depends on the context of "make".

If you're talking about making heaven and earth, yes, that means to create, but if you're talking about making a representation, that means presenting the representation to someone, not -- not drafting it for someone else to make.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: In the prospectus, there is a section on management that explains that Janus Capital Management engages in the day-to-day functions.
There are no employees of Janus Funds themselves.
All of this is outsourced management--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Except -- except when they review material going in the prospectus.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --But that--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Then they have independent representation by outside counsel.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Right.

What they don't have, Mr. Chief Justice, and where the falsity is here, is the ability of any of those outsiders to determine whether or not implementing the policy will be done fraudulently, and that's where the culpability is here.
JCM runs these funds, and although the statement might get accepted by the board of trustees--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I don't understand -- I don't understand your answer.
The outside counsel reviews what the policy is going to be?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Our question is the validity of that statement, whether that's deceptive in the prospectus.
That seems to me to be an entirely different question.
I understood your theory of the case to be that JCM is liable, basically, because they put it in the prospectus.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: And what they did was to falsely represent what they would do with that statement.
I would direct the Court to paragraph 5.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's the question, I guess, that -- your response seems to beg the question -- is that they falsely represented.
The issue is whether or not something happened between their drafting and its appearance in the prospectus.
That makes it appropriate to say that that's a statement of the trust rather than a statement of JCM.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: It is a statement of both, in the sense that the Fund is attracting investors, but the Fund is managed and controlled by the investment manager; here, JCM.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But if JCM falsely represented what it would do, it made that false representation to the Fund, and the Fund, as has been acknowledged, would have a cause of action against JCM.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But that's not what's going on here.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --No.
In fact, paragraph 5 of the complaint says Janus is representing that its mutual funds -- Janus Capital Management, its mutual funds -- were designed to be long-term investments.
It then says in paragraph 6:
"As recognized in the prospectuses, JCM purported market timing policy was designed to protect long-term investors. "

So if you read the prospectus and you read the complaint, it is absolutely clear what Janus Capital Management is telling all the mutual fund investors of the world: If you invest in Janus, we will protect your long-term investments.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What isn't clear from all of those things is that JCM made any representation to the public.
The representation was made in the prospectus issued by the Fund, not by JCM.

Now, the Fund may have a cause of action against JCM, but what's crucial here is whether -- whether you can establish that it is JCM who made the representation to the public, and I don't see how you can get there.
You might proceed under the control provision, but not by saying that they made the representation.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Justice Scalia, they wrote the prospectus.
They're--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: That's fine.
Just like writing a speech for somebody.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --And when they issued the prospectus, they used their address and represented to the public that they--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, but it seems be an important -- when they issued the prospectus?
Who issued the prospectus?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Sorry.
JCM filed it and disseminated it on its website, and all investors in the Janus Funds knew to -- knew to make inquiries to the manager if they had any question about the Funds.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If I carry a letter over and file it on behalf of some principal, does it become my letter?
Have I made that representation?
Sure, they filed it.
What does that prove?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Because it's--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: As you say, they have no other agents, unless the trustees themselves were going to walk over and file it.
JCM was functioning in that capacity as an employee of the Fund in the filing.
They didn't file it on their own behalf.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Yes, they did.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: On their own behalf?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Absolutely.
They created the fund, Justice Scalia.
That's how mutual funds work.
Managers create them, they lure investors to them, they get money by having a percentage of assets under management.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And the SEC has recognized that they remain two separate entities, despite the interconnected relationship.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Certainly, but there are many cases -- in fact, I don't think it's ever been disputed in the courts of appeals that if one company outsources its management function and those outsourced managers make lies on behalf of the company, they are also--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: The one activity -- one activity that we know they did not outsource was review of the materials submitted by JCM.
They had independent counsel that conducted that review.

Would it have been a breach of the trustees' fiduciary obligations to the fund investors under common law -- I forget where this is incorporated -- to rubberstamp what they get from somebody on the outside, not to have independent counsel review what they're going to say in their prospectus?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Mr. Chief Justice, my answer to your question is: That's actually a very difficult question under fiduciary duty law, because here, the fiduciaries have been duped themselves.

They, when they got the wording of the prospectus and the policy that JCM was purporting to implement -- JCM didn't tell the Board that there are 12 secret deals with hedge funds, pursuant to which we're going to make money by attracting long-term investors and make money with short-term market climbers--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Isn't that, again, what has been conceded: That there may well be an action from the Fund represented by their trustees against--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Common lawsuit for duping.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Justice Scalia, in no instance that I'm aware of where a mutual fund investment advisor is a publicly traded company would that cause of action run on behalf of the managers shareholders.
What we're talking about here is a company with a product, and they lie about the product.
And in that instance, it's no different from the Vioxx case last year with Merck or the difference from the cold remedy case you are going to hear argument in next term.
The mutual funds happen to be the product of the company.
They make misstatements about the product--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Suppose this case didn't involve a mutual fund.
Suppose it involved a corporation with thousands of employees and the prospectus is drafted by outside counsel.
It's adopted by the directors of the company without changing a word.
Now, would that case come out the same?
And if not, what would -- what exactly would you have us say to distinguish the two?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Well, the outside lawyers, I think, are distinguishable in a number of different ways.
One is that they are reacting on information provided by the company.
That information is typically not subject to an independent investigation by outside counsel to determine the truth or veracity of the information.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: What if it's alleged they knew exactly what was going on?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: If there is scienter, where the lawyers knowingly act in a way that helps or that contributes to that fraud, they may well be subject as aiders and abettors.
It depends on whether you can establish that the lawyers have met all of the elements.
I mean, you would have to show reliance.
You would have to show lost causation.
You would have to show the primary violation of the party--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And what are aiders and abettors?
I thought there wasn't aiding and abetting.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Sorry.
The SEC would be able to proceed against the lawyers for aiding and abetting.

Whether or not there would be a private action would depend on whether the lawyers -- it could be pleaded under the heightened pleading requirements that they had met all of the elements of the 10b-5 claim.
I would submit that's extremely difficult.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What is it that -- I'm unclear on this.
That's why I use the oil company example.
Plain, ordinary -- the top executives in the oil company write the false statement.
They give it to a board that doesn't know it's false, and the board puts it out in its name.
Now, it seems to me it ought to be clear at this point in securities law whether those -- the president and the vice president are or are not liable under this 10-b, the (b) part.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Yes, and we cited those cases--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And they are liable.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --i believe at page 37.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You're saying they are liable?
All right.

Then their response to that is: This is not like the president of the oil company, and the reason that it's not is something to do with the nature of the obligation that runs between the managers and the Fund, which is somehow different between -- you understand it better than I.
Can you say what it is and what you think your response is?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Yes.
What I will say is that they don't have a principal distinction between those two situations.
Simply having a contract to outsource management where those management functions of the company are resulting in false statements issued by the company shouldn't make--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So you're saying -- you're saying it shouldn't matter that -- if they issued worse if they run the whole company than if they're just the president?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
Now, at that point, we get into a problem, and the problem is how do we distinguish an aider or abettor from the principal?

At that point I am uncertain indeed, and that's why I put out this for comment, this suggestion that you follow criminal law here and say at least they are a principal if they have a high position, they participate in it, they do all these things you say, and the entity they're fooling in the first instance is simply a conduit, and therefore, you cannot say it's a scheme, because the other part of the scheme wasn't part of it.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Well, to be a primary violator, you have to have met all the elements of the cause of action.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: To be an aider and abettor for SEC enforcement purposes, you simply have to provide substantial assistance to one who is a primary violator.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What's the difference between substantial assistance and doing it?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: You would not have to make the statement.
You would do something to assist the person making the statement.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Frederick, I thought we had held -- I was sure we had held that there is no aiding and abetting liability--

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Yes.
I'm -- I'm not saying--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --under the provision we're discussing here.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: There's a distinction.
You want to say what the distinction is.
So I would say, consistent with the view, there is no aiding and abetting liability.
You still would win your case?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --That's correct, because there is no primary violator under JCM's view of the facts here.
They are the primary violator under our view of the facts here, because they met all of the elements of the 10b-5 action, and they had a motive do it, and they made--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Is your claim premised on Janus being duped or not?
If Janus was not duped, if its board knew and JCM was doing the activity with either the consent or acquiescence of the board, would you have a claim here?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --We would.
It would be somewhat different because we would plead multiple violators as the court and central bank and from which--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Then go back to Justice Breyer's question, because I can see when there's one primary violator who uses another entity as a dupe or as a puppet, but I can't, and I don't know how to distinguish what you're proposing, from aiding and abetting.
There has to be something to differentiate the two, so what is it?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --It's the failure on the part of the person who would not have met all of the elements of the 10b-5 claim.
You have to have someone -- you have two people, okay?
Both of them have to have satisfied all the elements of a 10b-5 claim to be primary violators.
If there is one element that is not satisfied with respect to that person, that person is only an aider and abettor and not subject to private remedies under Section 10(b).
They would be subject to aiding and abetting liability under the SEC.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: The distinction you're drawing is between making the statement and assisting in making the statement.
Isn't that what you just said?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Well, no, in the sense that we believe, and we assert in the complaint and the complaint is adequately pleaded, is that JCM made the statements.
Now--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, aiding and abetting is assisting in making these statements as if -- as in something you want to take place, right?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: What is the difference, the distinction in -- in this context?
One possible distinction is who formally makes it, in whose name is it made, but that's obviously not your -- your position.
So what is it to distinguish a principal here from an aider and abettor?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Who has substantive control over the content of the message.

That kind of substantive control, as -- as the Court in the Utah Ten Commandments case pointed out, the government can have speech attributed to it on the basis of it putting up a monument on public land.
There can be multiple speakers with respect to one message, and the question of how much substantive control you attribute to a particular speaker we believe is the appropriate way to view--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you deny that the Fund had substantive control?
Couldn't the Fund have stopped this statement from being placed in its prospectus?
Didn't it have outside lawyers who advised it whether it should allow this statement to be included in its prospectus?
How can you say that they -- they didn't have control?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Well, they did not have a knowledge of the falsity.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that may mean that they're duped, but it doesn't mean that they don't have control.
They had control, but you say they -- they were duped, but that's quite a different theory from saying that they had control -- that they didn't have control.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: No, Justice Scalia, they didn't have substantive control over the content of the message, because if they did, they would not have allowed these false statements to have been issued.

And that's the whole point -- that's the theory here, JCM was luring long-term investors with the promise, if you park your money with the Janus Funds, it will be safe in -- from the kinds of market timing problems.
They were then secretly going out and luring money from the hedge funds for then--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But there is -- there is nothing in the record to indicate that that statement was attributed to JCM?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --The public understood it that way.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You can -- you can play with the words, JCM?
I -- I see nothing in -- in the record that would justify that.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Well, JA 275A, Justice -- Justice Kennedy -- excuse me -- says that Janus Capital Management reserved the Janus name for itself.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: How did it reserve that?
You said twice in your brief that Janus is a name to which JCM reserves the right.
How did it reserve the right?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: It said, and this is at page 275A, if for some reason Janus Capital Management's contract is terminated, the Funds can no longer use the Janus name.
They were intending to trademark and get the name out there to attract investors to the investment advisor's method of investing.
And it was that type of usage that brought all of this together.
The Fund and the management, they are in function essentially one entity.
The fact that they have contractually outsourced the management function should not alleviate the securities fraud that is alleged here.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Frederick, a substantial part of the power of your argument comes from this notion that, as Justice Ginsburg said, that JCM was in the driver's seat, that JCM had control, that they were -- Janus was at most an alter ego of JCM and maybe something more, that it was just a creature of JCM.
But the securities legislation seems to deal with that in section 20.
And your case is not brought under section 20, and because of the relationship between mutual funds and their investment advisors, presumably could not be brought under section 20.
So, why should we think relevant the kind of controlled relationship that you're talking about?

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Because you don't want to create a road map for other people to commit fraud, Justice Kagan, and that's what their theory does.

What their theory does is it says is we set up shell companies or if we dupe people to make statements, we can commit securities fraud with impunity, because we won't be held liable to having made the statement, even though we wrote it, we had substantive control over it, et cetera.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Except, except to the SEC, right?
Because they can pursue it under aiding and abetting.
It's kind of a big--

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --problem if you're trying to say we're safe from the actions for security fraud.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --Well, Chief Justice Roberts, this Court on numerous occasions has said that the private securities action is a complement to the enforcement efforts of the SEC, and in this instance, the shareholders of the investment--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I know, but you were just responding by saying the problem is that this will give people a road map.
But they're going to hit a pretty big bump in the road when the SEC brings an action against them, including potential criminal actions.

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --But, no, the problem, Mr. Chief Justice, is that under their construction of the facts there's no primary violator.
Mr. Perry said this morning--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: The SEC--

turn.speaker: david_c_frederick
turn.label: Mr. David C. Frederick
turn.text: --there's no primary violator.
And, so, if there's no primary violator, there can be no controlled person and there can be no aiding and abetting.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Frederick.
Mr. Gannon.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Counsel, could you start by taking your brief and distilling it down to three sentences?
Define what a primary violator is, what a secondary violator is who aids and abets, and who a control person is?
And then tell me how that definition would exclude lawyers, auditors, investment -- general investment advisors, et cetera.
I've read your brief, but I've been trying to distill it down to three sentences.
So try to do that for me.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --A primary violator must be somebody who has actually committed all the elements of a 10b-5--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Give me an example of that.
What do you see as all of the elements?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, the elements for the private cause of action are the ones that this Court has repeated.
They are--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: I understand.
But--

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --In this case the key one we're talking about is you would need to be an actual maker of the statement, and -- and--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --And that becomes -- how is that different from aiding and abetting the making of a statement?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --It -- we think that somebody can make a statement if they create the statement, and the statute and the rule both expressly apply to those who make statements directly--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But that's every lawyer--
--who writes the false statement knowing it's false.
So, are you saying every lawyer who writes the statement knowing that it's false is a primary--

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Scienter is another element, and so a lawyer who just reviews the policy, JCM in this case, when JCM submitted false statements to the funds, if the funds were unaware, this is where Mr. Frederick concluded for the Chief Justice that if there -- if the person who actually releases the statement to the world has been duped and doesn't have scienter, then there is -- they are not going to be--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So, just to get--

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --A primary violator.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --to get back, so you are conceding that if you lose this case, you will be unable to bring any aiding and abetting case in a situation such as this?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: Under sections 20 -- it depends on what the situation--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: It seems like a yes or no question.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Yes, if the situation here is one in which the Funds ultimately cannot be proved to have scienter.
If they did not know about the falsity of the statements in the prospectuses that they released to the public, then there would not be a primary violator.

Under section 20(e) for aiding and abetting liability, the Commission can bring an aiding and abetting claim against somebody who provides substantial assistance, recklessly or knowingly -- recklessly or knowingly provides substantial assistance to a primary violator, but the Court has repeatedly made clear that a primary violator needs to have violated all of the elements of a 10b-5 cause of action which includes--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: I'm still not clear what your distinction is between making the statement and aiding and abetting in the making of the statement.
Now, could you explain that for me?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, I think that--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Is it necessary that the person in whose -- the entity in whose name the statement is made is an empty shell, it's simply a puppet that's controlled by somebody else?
Is that -- is that necessary or does it go beyond that?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --No, I don't think that that's necessary.

If the position -- the position that the Commission has taken is that somebody who makes a statement, if he writes the statement or provides the false information that's used to construct the statement or allows the statement to be attributed to him, and we think that that's a reasonable construction of the term "make", because the statute and the rule both apply to persons who make the statement directly or indirectly.
And, so, they could be using a conduit, whether the conduit is witting or unwitting, they would be a primary violator if they had--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't think that's a reasonable interpretation of -- of -- of make a statement indirectly.
I mean, you can make it indirectly by not issuing it yourself but having somebody else make it in your name.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, if--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But I would not say I'm making a speech indirectly if I have drafted the speech.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, but if--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The person for whom I drafted the speech is making the speech.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, that may be true in the case of a speech, Justice Scalia, but in a classic boiler room situation, where somebody has written the scripts for salespersons to -- to use in order to make calls to sell stocks, the person who actually writes the scripts may never speak the words to a customer, he may never have his own name spoken on the phone, and therefore, the statements have not been attributed to him--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: He may just be some poor associate, his first day at work.
The law firm sent him there and he got stuck down in the boiler room.
And somebody said, why don't you write something that will get everybody to sell things, and -- and why don't you say we're a thousand tons of oil instead of only a ton.
In -- he writes it out.
You think he's liable?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --If he writes it out and he doesn't know, he obviously isn't liable--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, no, at some level he knows,
"I shouldn't be saying they found 1,000 tons of oil when they only found 50. "
okay?
And four people told him to go do something like that, but he's the guy who wrote it.
I would say he didn't behave well, but I don't think he's the principal.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --In that instance, because he was acting specifically at the direction of superiors--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They didn't say what words to write.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --They gave--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: They gave him the general idea, and then he did it.
He created the words, to use your phrase; when you say creating the words, he's a great writer.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --It -- we do, on page 22, acknowledge that somebody needs to be sufficiently involved in the creation or dissemination of the statement in order to be -- in order to be deemed its maker or its author.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Ah, now we have "sufficiently involved".

Once we're into sufficiently involved, we're back into what is sufficient to make the person the principal rather than the aider and the abettor, and apparently creating or writing the statement is not clear whether it is or is not sufficient.
So we're back into the problem.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: In this instance there's no doubt that the manager of the funds was not a mere advisor.
They bodily--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I'm interested in your test.
I'm interested in your test, not the--

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well, the -- the test does acknowledge that -- that if there is not sufficient control over the content of the -- the message and the dissemination of it that somebody may be more in an advisory capacity.
That might be the instance with lots of outside law firms when they're acting at the specific direction of counsel.
That's not the situation of--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: In that connection, just again, would you answer the -- the statement that Mr. Perry made that the government had, in fact conceded that this theory would spread, not only to -- to the investment advisor so closely linked to funds but to every lawyer, every accountant, every bank.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You said you said that on page something here.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --We said that -- he was referring to the statement on page 22 of the government's brief, referring to the need -- for the -- for the author to be sufficiently involved in creating or disseminating the statement.
And I think it's very important to recognize that scienter is an important limiting -- limiting principle for the 10b-5 cause of action.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that will always be charged.
It's the simplest thing in the world to charge scienter.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: It would be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you've bought yourself a big lawsuit.

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: --It's not simple, Justice Scalia, in light of the PSLRA, there requires it to be alleged with articularly; there need to be facts sufficient to give rise to a strong inference that the defendant acted with scienter, and -- and there are penalties beyond rule 11 that are -- that are imposed if the -- if the plaintiff is -- is mistaken in doing so.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: You think attribution to the actor is not necessary for the actor's liability for his statement?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: That's correct.
We think that -- and any other rule would immunize falsely attributed or anonymous statements.

And if the whole purpose of a fraud was to convince somebody that this statement came from Warren Buffet, so that I could turn a quick buck before the market realized that it wasn't actually from Warren Buffett, the fact that it was not attributed to me would not change the fact that I had made the statement and that the market had relied upon it.
The truth is that reasonable investors, and that's the test for purposes of reliance, can rely on anonymous and falsely attributed statements.
In this instance there's no reason to doubt that an investor would have relied on statements in the prospectus about the fund's purported antimarket timing and excessive trading policies.

And so we think that there -- in general there doesn't need to be an attribution requirement, but in this instance it's quite clear that a reasonable investor could have relied on these -- prospectus.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --Counsel, could you have -- you just admitted if there -- if the company was duped, you couldn't have aiding and abetting liability.
Could you impose a 20(b) or 20(b) control person liability?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: The control person liability also needs to have a primary violator under the terms of 20(a).

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Gannon, suppose that we think that the test that the SEC is using and you recite on page 13 is really pretty broad and that it might apply to a range of factual situations that are not before us.
Is there a way to confine our holding just to the mutual fund situation, and if there is, how would you do that?

turn.speaker: curtis_e_gannon
turn.label: Mr. Curtis E. Gannon
turn.text: Well, I think the easiest way would be to analogize it to the cases involving corporate employees.
As Petitioners acknowledge, there are cases where a corporate employee drafts a statement that's issued in the company's name.

In this instance the investment advisor is management for the company, and the fact that they happen to be management by virtue of contract rather than just the internal arrangements of the corporation shouldn't change that arrangement.
